Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: That's true that personalities play a big role.  In Kindergarten I have students work in pairs a lot at different activities and the number one factor I have to look at is how the two will work together. If they enjoy being together, then there are good results.

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Thanks <redacted> and <redacted> - your comments were right along my line of thinking. I'm a middle and high school teacher and I erroneously thought that students started to gain the \can't do\" math around grade 5 or 6 - due to the fact that the material gets more abstract (this is where algebraic ideas generally begin in curricula). Boy was I in for a shock when I interviewed a 5-year old who said she was bad at math! FIVE?? With all I have learned this year, this isn't so surprising anymore, but is all the more disheartening. I believe that \"struggle\" - mentioned by <redacted> -  is something that needs to be seen in a more positive light - as PART of the learning process. So often teachers and parents are quick to \"rescue\" a child from a perceived struggle rather than allow students to let their intuition loose on a problem. This can be one of many ways, as <redacted> says, that teacher beliefs can influence the non-verbal ways they communicate that a students can't do math."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: At third grade we have heterogeneous classrooms but we are beginning  to pull leveled intervention ability groups.  Where does this leave us?  I feel that these students will receive work that is too easy, there will be middle group teaching and definitely borderline causalities.  Most importantly, these students know that they are being pulled into a special group and that will give them a fixed mindset. My current solution is to rationalize that the ability group will only be for a 45 minute portion of the day. Perhaps there is another solution and the intervention teacher can work in the classroom? Other ideas would be appreciated.

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I understand your concerns.  In my grade six class I have 30 students of all different abilities.  It can be difficult some days to make sure everyone is progressing along their own personal continuum.  Some days I allow students to choose their own groups to work through problems and other days I direct students to pairings which may be more beneficial then their friends.  Approximately 70% of my students tend to choose their group wisely; and I do not mean based on ability, more importantly, the ability to cooperate together.  The best discussions tend to come from students who are of mixed ability and they really talk through the problems.  Unfortunately 30% of my students need help cooperating with their peers.  I have to remind them how to listen and share respectively.  For a few students it takes most of the class just to settle into a group and start the problem, while others finish the work in no time.  Facility these classes can be challenging but it can also be extremely rewarding.

It wasn't always students who were struggling.  I think it was good for all students to see that it's OK to get support from the teacher."

I'll let them know, as I always do, that I love questions and looking at mistakes.  To really drive this point home, though, I'll follow through during the school year by highlighting student mistakes during lessons, in homework review, and after assessments.  I'll also allow students time to correct their mistakes and learn from them."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I think that the dot representation allows people to break free of the rules that are associated with numbers and think along more flexible lines. The question \What do you see\" rather than \"what is the answer\" is important here. _x0007_The subsequent explanation of what do you see and HOW do you see it, allows many different ways of seeing the same set of dots. _x0007_It is important because many of us get stuck in seeing things from one point of view or perspective. Seeing how others see it is opens up new perspectives."

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Back in the day, when I was in school :), I remember vividly being in the \high\" math group.  Sure, this helped me, but what did it do for the other students in the \"middle\" and \"low\" groups?  Fast forward 30 years.  I have been teaching for 22 years - from K-8, \"regular\" ed to special ed.  I am currently at a school that chose to ability group the students this year.  I was against it from the start (and still am), but I was overruled.  I guess I should have done some extra homework to find the studies on ability grouping...sigh.  It's hard enough to get teachers \"off the textbook\" and have their students THINK.  Now I see it's even MORE important because of the way my school set up the classes."

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: The students did not feel compeled to use only one method. They liked to decomopose and add numbers. They like to think of ways to solve a problem. I loved the idea of friendly numbers - numbers that you could combine easily. They weren't afraid to make a mistake in class. They saw that as an opportunity for the others in the class to help them. This was a community learning environment where there was give and take among the students. They worked well together. They really liked their teacher and felt like he was helping them.It was good to see young students so excited about learning math.

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I am glad that these students like math so much.  When math is seen as a puzzle, as something fun, and not a panic inducing moment of trying to remember WHAT process, procedure, whatever, to do, the students really enjoy it.  I found it interesting that the boys brought up freedom so much.  I know that academic choice in projects, LA, reading, science, and Social Studies is very important so that students start to take ownership of their learning process and become engaged at a deeper level.  It was nice to see differentiation of a math level, that the students could choose between one of two problems.  This choice was further enforced when different ways of approaching the problem were given, discussed, and valued.  Since these kids saw math as a fun and free activity, they may love math for a long time.  YEAH!

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I agree! It's not just T-Shirts for girls, though. I hate the gender neutral ones that say things like, \I stopped listening a long time ago!\" Why parents buy T-Shirts for their children that underscore a negative message is a mystery to me. One time I made a fake T-Shirt slogan and wore it as I greeted my class. I tried to behave as normal, but the message on the shirt was insulting to every reader. The students had quite a reaction to that T-shirt! I followed that experience up by talking about the power of the messages we wear and had the students design their own T-Shirt with a positive message that would build our community up rather than tearing it down. The problem is that the parents did not like me criticizing their choice in clothing their child. So I never did it again, but believe me, I think it's a huge issue!"

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: This is an interesting question for me._x0007__x0007_I shall soon be teaching maths to a small group of home educated children aged 11-13 who represent an extreme of mix of prior maths knowledge. Some of them have done varying amounts of formal maths, while I think a few won't have done any at all (that is not to say they won't all have used some mathematical ideas and concepts in some way, just not formally in the way that is usual for most folks who've been to school)._x0007__x0007_I will have the advantage that the group will probably not exceed 10 students though I'm still not sure whether I should attempt to have them all working on the same projects or not as I do have concerns about how to engage and not frighten away those with limited prior maths knowledge while at the same time challenging those who have done a lot before.  _x0007__x0007_I can see from this course so far that it may not be quite as much of a problem as I had previously thought, however if I have a question, I suppose it would be to ask _x0007__x0007_1) Do you think that there is a point at which the two extremes of the class become too far away from each other for a mixed ability setting to work?_x0007__x0007_2) Where might that point be?

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Yes, my 6th graders just want to jump in and solve the problem. Looking for numbers to push around and operations that can be attached without any reasoning or sense makingits justI have some numbers, division seems like a good choice and there you go. They have no idea how to check for accuracy, because their parts dont connect._x0007__x0007__x0007_At the beginning of the year we battled across the lines to get them to decompose/deconstruct problems and then reconstruct them. I had to take away finding the solution as the solution. The solution became to take the problem apart and create models with number sentences attached. We started to celebrate elaborate deconstructions, especially ones with engaging visuals/models. I wasnt able to march through the math program with the pace necessary to deconstruct and problem solve at the pace required, however, we did become better and more eager detectives. Thus said, it takes more than one school years worth of deep diving into problems to change habits. If their 7th grade teacher goes back to highlighting solutions rather than processes they will fall right back into their old patterns. _x0007__x0007__x0007_My K-5 colleagues are right there with me however, and more and more I should see students coming into 6th grade with a focus on decomposing/deconstructing problems in multiple ways (find 3 ways) to determine solutions.  The CCSS mathematical practices will all encourage deeper thinking in mathematical processes. _x0007__x0007_I really want my students to start math problems with doodling. This is going to be my focus this year so here is my acronym that the students and I will begin to play with at the beginning of the year, morphing over time as they take ownership._x0007__x0007__x0007_DRAW!_x0007__x0007_D-Dig in, Doodle, Deconstruct the problemDelete the extraneous. _x0007__x0007_R-Reason as you godoes this make sense?_x0007__x0007_A-Apply your reasoning to mathematical number sentences._x0007__x0007_W- Write your process in logical steps that anybody could follow. _x0007__x0007_!-Celebrate!! You have increased your brain mass and connections to success. _x0007__x0007__x0007_Stages:_x0007_Relax and Read like there is a hidden treasure inside the problem. _x0007_Keys to open the Treasure Box_x0007_Key 1-What is the question(s)?_x0007_Key 2- Re-read with the question in mind and highlight key ideas (the deconstruction begins)_x0007_Key 3- Get rid of the noise- cross out obvious extraneous information to reduce clutter. _x0007_Key 4- Start doodling what you read- Illustrate or Model the highlighted parts _x0007_Key 5- Attach values and number sentences where it makes sense_x0007_Key 6

It can also help students identify where we teachers aren't providing the resources the kids need!

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I thought it was interesting that one of the boys kept talking about how free math is.  How you can do anything you want.  It was also interesting that one boy thought it didn't help sometimes but we never heard why he thought it didn't help.  They used the word decompose often and I am curious when that word became part of their math vocabulary.  I wonder if they have a common understanding of the word or if it is a new word for them in fourth grade and they are still developing an understanding of what it means.  Having taught 4th grade in the past, I know that they are eager learners and they love to learn new things.  It is a wonderful age for students to realize there is freedom in learning.  I now work at the middle level and I wonder when and why student enthusiasm about learning math seems to lessen or disappear.  Could this lack of excitement be about the tracking that happens at middle school?  Could it be that they aren't yet confident related to number sense and fluency and it isn't something we focus on at the middle level?  How can we keep students excited about learning math as they work at the middle level?  Maybe doing more with developing their number sense and fluency through the use of math talks could bring back their confidence and excitement?

It also leads to far more interesting responses for assessment.   The challenge for the teacher is in coming up with substantive options that allow for different forms of expression while expecting learners to concentrate on the same learning goals. There is an art to differentiation, and it is an area for skill development and practice for every teacher. There are many ways to differentiate instruction and/or assignments. You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I am not sure whether any setting can be justified, however there is a great deal of mileage in enabling students to aspire. As a head of mathematics at a secondary school in the UK I have often been asked how can we ensure we are adding value to each and every child, thereby enabling each child to fulfil their potential and grow as students of mathematics. I agree with many of Jo Boaler's sentiments especially giving students implicit fixed mindset messages regarding setting arrangements in schools, which has given me much food for thought. Setting does pose a number of issues, none more so than students being pigeonholed into a stereotype, as attainment within set 1 within one struggling school could be working at the same standard as a student within set 4 of a geographically and socio-economically different school considered outstanding. That said as a school that does set its students there are a range of supporting mechanisms that I think we use well, which can help alleviate some of the fixed mindset messages she talks about. One of the main ones involves team teaching opportunities which involves teaming up students within various groups to complete tasks, equally setting tasks across year groups and encouraging students to complete assignments collaboratively, with another students from another group. Equally i feel strongly that students can achieve a sense of achievement in the maths classroom by drawing on a variety of creative strands. Using cross curricular strands which celebrate other aspects of school life, and particular strengths of the students. These opportunities may draw upon skills that students may consider to be outside the normal parameters of the mathematics classroom. Also much of mathematical attainment is closely allied to motivation to learn. Some of those motivations can be intrinsic in nature. However it is my experience that students view a mathematics qualification as desirable as it enables them to access other qualifications and career paths. Mathematics therefore as a gatekeeper qualification is one of the necessary career related and dependent qualifications, therefore there can be some mileage in informing students of opportunities open to them and using that as a driver for performance, therefore taking away issues and comparisons with peer attainment.

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I teach at a private school and we have always had tracking in the middle school and high school levels. Until this past year, we also had tracking at the elementary level. When I came to the school I brought up how ability grouping at the elementary level in subjects like math is really kind of pointless. Many of the students who are deemed \gifted\" at the elementary level are those that are good at math facts, not math reasoning/thinking. It's these same students who are later held up in mathematics at the middle school or high school level where more thinking is involved. I teach at the middle school level, and we have tracked students for the upcoming school year and as I am working to prepare for this, I am working to set expectations for each set of students that will challenge each set of students. The students at each grade level are learning the same material, but at different paces. I want to expect the same end goal for each set, but take the expectation and spread it out over the time needed for each set of students to understand and make sense of the material on their own. I am really excited about this because I have hopes that I will see lots of growth for both groups and I challenge them to reach something that they will see as unreachable at the time."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I teach high school chemistry and I have two levels of groups: a regular level and honors level. My observations are of two sides: _x0007__x0007_1. I cannot imagine these two levels mixed! My high achievers would be bored to death and will just not show up. My lower level students will get lost, will shut out, and will not show up either. I believe that, at least in high school, division into ACHIEVEMENT levels (not ABILITY levels!) is very important. It provides an opportunity for better prepared students to stay interested and engaged, and learn more. It also affords students less prepared more time to work on the concepts and, again, learn more._x0007__x0007_2. On another hand, the division is far from perfect and each of these groups contains mixed levels. There are students placed in the wrong level, either higher or lower than fits their readiness level. In all cases it would be a disaster to ignore the obvious disconnect. I think that ANY two students are on two levels and require differentiated approach. It is up to the teacher to recognize \misplaced\" students and prepare materials on a few levels inside each grouping. It is very hard to do, no doubts. With our already super-busy overload, it is hard to find the time and energy to prepare multilevel lessons, however it is critical for student learning. In addition to that, we all stay after school to help those who still need more time and more training._x0007__x0007_So the bottom line: achievement grouping is needed (at least in high school math and sciences), but it does not replace a teacher who teaches all learners on many levels."

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Students form their identity around the courses they take.  They have a math identity.  By tracking or putting them in groups by ability, we are preassigning that identity for them and for everyone else.  Student's assigned to certain \level\" of classes(low, medium, high, honors,etc) now have this image of themselves as that descriptor.  Once student's are put in those classes and are tracked (which happens at an early age), parents, teachers and society buy in to said descriptor.  Oh Tommy, he is ok at math but not great because he is the middle class. Or Jenny is great at math she is in honors.  There is a lot of pressure and identity assigned along the continuum that supports a fixed mindset.  Jenny is less likely to take risks in math lest she loose her standing.  Upward or downward mobility is limited and those on the bottom will likely remain there through high school and those on top fear of losing this position.  Mathematical achievement of the individual begins to ossify with this identity or class level.  Students on the \"lower\" end will achieve to the standard that has been assigned and no more.  While students at the \"higher\" end will also be cautious in achievement because they have been held to a higher standard of \"smart\" and do not want to loose it."

I know that most of you have a dislike for the math that you've been taught since you've attended school. However, it my job to introduce you to real mathematics. In real math you get to work with problems, where you are going to make mistakes along the way to a solution. Don't be afraid of mistakes. I want to even welcome the mistakes because it is in the making of mistakes that we learn. The more mistakes you make the more you will learn. As a matter of fact, I'm not even concerned about how many \right\" answers you get. What I am concerned about is that you learn the beauty of math, and how there is math all around. Not so much in figuring out problems that make on sense, but opening your eyes to see creation's patterns and how things are related in life. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I've heard negative math messages from parents, media, students, other teachers, self-driected messages... and the list goes on. I think it often has to do with the way that math is graded. Students lose points for one thing after another (even if they have already been docked marks for the mistake at a previous point in their work) and are rarely congratulated or acknowledged for the amazing progress that they make in processes that they do understand. I have a student that scored incredibly low in another math class even though her understanding and thinking processes were incredibly advanced. It's extremely discouraging to be told that you're not good at something, especially when you are. Also there seems to be this notion floating around that if you get something wrong that you don't understand it. Getting something \wrong\" is often a simple computation error that doesn't indicate whether or not the greater concept was understood. And getting something \"wrong\" just means that there is room for more exploration, not that something will never be understood."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: This past school year, I taught a Grade 9/10 split locally developed math course. It is the lowest level tracked math class.  As I worked with the students, I realized that while a few of them were there because they were low achieving, the majority of them were there because of outside issues.  The majority were in and out of school because of issues at home (children's aid society, sick parents, emancipated from their parents, etc.)  It wasn't that they were not capable of doing math, but that they ended up missing so much school time and there were huge gaps in their knowledge.  As I tried to fill in the gaps (I don't know how successful I was with everyone), achievement started to improve.  When I spoke with the head of Student Success, I voiced concerns that a few students were improperly placed.  That the class was beneath them once they were caught up on the concepts but they weren't promoted to the next level._x0007__x0007_If the students were grouped by need (a class that moved at a slower pace, allowing them more time to catch up on concepts they missed due to personal reasons), I think they would have performed much better.  I do not know how that would work in a school environment, but I think it is definitely something to think about.

I am worried for the very small percentage of kids who thrive on a math challenge if we completely eliminate tracking. (I had students who would skip a birthday party rather than miss an after school math contest class.  It was that important to them.)  I think it is all about the messaging, and then making sure that the various levels are open to all who are interested in doing what it takes to be successful."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I do think the methods that are used to teach math are inadequate. I began teaching in 1993 and the curriculum used at first school I worked at was ARISE, a problem based math program that took big problems and expected kids to work in groups and solve things together. They would ponder and struggle and then the next lesson would give them help and clarification. It was a good first step, but it had problems--for a new teacher, it was hard to really know what my role was, how to lead and guide kids effectively. But it was real math (my BS was mechanical engineering, and though I always tested well in math, I never understood the point until we were required to model physical situations mathematically junior and senior year). Within 5 year, everything shifted in California. We left off any pretense of teaching kids to think and were expected to spend all our time showing kids procedures and trying to get them to memorize them. _x0007__x0007_I am getting long winded here, but what I am finding is that the kids in our district who are tracked into the lowest classes (yes, our district returned to tracking for a while) were kids who required meaning. At the end of the page? where the \word\" problems are? With a group of low track kids, I could ask questions and they would figure it out. With the \"smart\" kids, they would say \"Just tell me the formula\" and get angry and frustrated when I tried to help them think about what was going on. _x0007__x0007_That being said, in our district, the desperate lack of basic skills really compounds the problem when I get them at the middle school level. I would expect and encourage my students to think about this problem and in doing so visualise three slices of turkey. We cannot 'expect' them to assume all three to be exactly the same weight, to do so is to introduce some of the very issues this course is trying to resolve. If the answer is two and a quarter slices we have to tell the students to assume equal weight slices or, better still, ask them to describe what assumptions they have made in reaching this answer. The correct answer to this problem is that the man can eat three quarters of what he has bought. My next question to students would be \How do you think the man can make sure he is eating the correct amount of turkey for his diet?\"."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: In our independent school we begin tracking in 6th grade with two levels of math. Other subjects are not tracked at all. I know tracking sends negative fixed mindset messages to students at both levels.  However, developmentally we see huge differences in students' readiness and access to certain concepts, so we have been okay with the system.  Our teachers do a great, purposeful job offering open, challenging tasks to all students in both classes.  We are aware of and do our best to counteract fixed messages.  We take all kids from where they are developmentally and provide challenging, open tasks to support growth and develop deep conceptual understandings.  The issue (and our challenge) highlighted by the research is this:  even though we think we are offering a growth experience for all children, is this even possible within our tracked structure? Are the fixed messages just too powerful?_x0007_Also, we have lots of problems with parents, who often think their children are gifted and should advance to a higher class quickly even without strong foundational experiences.  So we have parents requesting their child \move up\", even though we believe it would not be in the student's best interest. There is often tension that hurts our partnership with the family.  Many times the child ends up frustrated._x0007_These are crucial issues, and we need to keep thinking and working to get it right."

In fact, we have been talking about it in class a lot.  Well, I thought I was pretty clever and I gave them a challenge math problem the other day. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: In Spain we usually don't group students by their abilities and in fact I think that it is forbidden by our laws. However, there have been some approaches to grouping recently:_x0007__x0007_- In Maths, Spanish and English (the so-called 'instrumental' subjetcs), in some schools, three groups are made out of every two, grouping the students according to their level. The intention is having a lower amount of students in the \low achievement group\" and then try to help them improve and catch the rest of their mates. This rarely happens. But teachers do say (I myself have never been assigned to such a group) that this grouping allows them to work with students who otherwise would be 'dead soldiers' in the classroom. I am talking about students who can't add or subtract, who can't name basic geometric figures and that, therefore, are unable to follow the path of a normal class. These students, as I say, do not usually catch up with the rest... but at least they are doing some work and avoiding illiteracy._x0007__x0007_- I teach in a bilingual program where we use CLIL methodology to help our students with their English while we work on Maths, Science, History etc... There are no limitations to join in the program but the number of places offered. If the demand exceeds the offer then the places are drawn. Nevertheless, parents (and teachers) tend to think that if their child has struggled with school without getting great results, then they should'n apply to this program because it would be 'too much'. Therefore, the bilingual groups are usually composed of higher achievers. These groups are usually easier to deal with (as their behaviour is far better than a 'regular group') but they do tend to consider themselves as 'the clever ones' and it affects the effort they put on their learning (they often consider bad results as totally unexpected... they ARE smartd, they SHOULD get high qualifications without much effort!"

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Picture an elementary classroom where students circle a part of the perimeter on a Friday morning. Beginning on one side of the room, each child in turn is given a multiplication fact to complete with the correct answer or return to their seats. A limited amount of time is given to each student because the teacher does not want to \waste too much time\". The same students are left standing at the end each week; these kids are known as the smart kids. The students who return to their seats quickly learn that they are not very smart. The students who are left standing as the last student face the taunts of classmates outside at recess: \"teacher's pet\" and a variety of other name-calling. Is this scenario from the 60's? Yes, but it is also present in the daily life of the elementary classroom of some schools in 2013. The clear message is that you need to be fast and correct in order to be smart. In a world of high-stakes testing, teachers worry more and more about time. Learning needs to be fast-paced, fast enough to present the correct outcomes on the mid-year and end-of-the-year tests. But not all children find their own understanding of mathematical concepts like multiplication on the same timetable. It is also very disheartening to see that we still have not overcome the stereotype of girls are not good at math. Why would any teacher want a child to believe that they were not capable of success in some area of mathematics just because their skin color is not white? Equity means success for all. When students enter this advanced track they are moved onto Algebra as an 8th grade and then Geometry as a freshmen. Those students who are placed into the traditional 7th grade class move onto 8th grade math and then Algebra as a freshmen. These students are stuck in this track and our school has not plan for students to move out of the tracking.  In other words, a student in the traditional tracking is stuck in that track until high school._x0007__x0007_I have very mixed reviews on our grouping of students. I have always felt badly for students who love math and are ready for challenging work when they are in a class where the majority of students are not ready for such work.  I also feel badly for those students who have gaps in their learning and throw up their hands when placed with students who appear to understand everything in math.  _x0007__x0007_The other challenge with mixed grouping is the supporting the mental state of the teacher.  Creating lessons which are tiered is challenging for teachers who have 5+ classes a day.  How do we save our teachers from burning out?  We place our students in grouped classes.  However, many teachers will then create tiered lessons for these grouped classes which is now further work for the teacher.  How do we challenge all students, not track, not group and create a growth mindset?

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Many students view their education as a series of tasks to be completed, rather than a means of preparation for the tasks of adulthood; they quantify the point of termination rather than grasping the concept of lifelong learning. Thus, this mindset lowers the priority given education. They see lessons and courses as things to be completed; skills learned are not put fully to use because there is minimal pressure to do so. An analogy is learning to drive: You study a book of rules and regulations to pass a test for a learners permit, which is used to actually practice operating the vehicle. You then demonstrate highway and parking skills and are awarded a license. At that point, a marginal (knowledgable, yet unexperienced and potentially dangerous) driver joins all others. It is continued practice, full of trial and errors, that makes this person a more competent driver ... until old age begins reversing the process. The incentives for improvement driving skills are the likelihood of killing oneself or others, loss of driving privileges due accidents, and expense of vehicle repairs and medical costs. Math, like driving, is a series of skills that must be used (applied) in order to be retained, used successfully and improved.

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Homogeneous vs. heterogeneous grouping has been a hot topic in school lately! While I enjoy teaching the honors students, there is a dimension missing in an average classroom once the top students are removed. Aside from the fixed mindset of many of the students and the lack of previous challenges in their math education, the dynamic is off. Having a wide range of abilities serves all students. Lower achieving students benefit from the knowledge of the higher achievers. They have a greater range of strategies to pull from. The higher achieving students also benefit, having additional opportunities to demonstrate their knowledge to a different audience. They also get a lesson in perseverance, often not experienced by higher achieving students devoid of challenges.

One thing I'm not seeing discussed here is learning style.  It really seems to me that some students need more or less time to internalize new ideas and notations, and I try to frame placement when talking to parents and students as being more about style than ability.  So I think that when not at the mercy of a bureaucracy and high-stakes tests, it is possible to avoid most of the specific factors that cause tracking to result in lower results.  I do agree that we should do a better job of encouraging growth mindset in our accelerated students."

Prof. Kurt Fischer's research at HGSE has shown that learning development is not linear but proceeds in a sort of upward trending saw tooth type waveform. This means that you could get wildly different results of children's ability depending on how well their learning development is \"in phase\", as it were._x0007__x0007_My small research group uses proprietary wireless keyboards to allow each child to answer each question in parallel. We provide representations of class responses immediately after the responses have come in. We subsequently analyse how student performance can be improved through studying the archives of student responses._x0007__x0007_We believe this motivates each child because each child is responded to. Additionally, children retain their own privacy as we do not identify individual responses in the representations. I think that we fundamentally share a strong belief that performance is a function of effort and persistence, and somehow the children pick up on this thinking._x0007__x0007_We also found almost zero instances of indiscipline in a 30 hour study. Finally we found that our maths curriculum which is almost totally at variance with the school curriculum resulted in the experimental group registering significant improvement over the control group even in end of term tests run by the school. The average change in performance based on US developed placement tests went from <25% to >75%._x0007__x0007_We have videos of the classes and the report of the study is available at www.agem.in/pdf/BriefReport.pdf"

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: At one of the schools I taught at the grade level (elementary) teachers began to have \math classes\" for the parents, to teach them what they were teaching the children.  These were like twice a month and helped some to overcome a \"misunderstanding\" many of the parents had regarding math.  It also helped them to \"learn\" math, so that they were able to help their children.  The other effect of this was that it raised the self-esteem of the parents, so that they didn't feel ignorant around their children.  _x0007_ _x0007_Several of the schools I have taught at require the students to keep a notebook, that includes the vocabulary they are learning with definitions and pictures / models, and every time they cover a new concept, everything that the teacher puts on the board to teach the steps to do it, are recorded by the student in their notebook.  They then are required to take the notebook home nightly and use it to study by, as to do homework by, so if they forget how to do something, it is in the notebook.  At the beginning of the year, the parents are told about the notebook, so that they know they can look in it also, to learn how to do a new method.  It also gives the parents an opportunity to admire the child's work in the notebook.  Notebooks are generally checked at least once a month, oftentimes weekly in the beginning.  Notebooks include a table of contents to help them find what they need to study / do.  The notebook idea went over so well, that other core subjects are doing it also.  The other benefit, is when the child swears they haven't been taught the method, the proof is in the notebook, if not theirs (cause they refused to write / whatever) it will be in a classmates.  Teachers always did a notebook also, for each class they taught, so they would know exactly what they had said, and what they hadn't, for parent conferences."

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Having taught math at the elementary and high school levels, I have seen how many of the elementary teachers are uncomfortable with math themselves.  The teachers often do not have a strong foundation on which to build a variety of entry points for their students, which in turn causes their students to have a less-than-ideal foundation for the next level.  In addition, the first time that a student is held accountable for their own learning is Algebra 1.  This is the first math course that they encounter that requires them to show mastery before moving on.  Students can literally fail math from kindergarten through 8th grade, but will typically still be passed on to the next grade level.  The \buck stops\" at high school Algebra, where so many students are completely unprepared that they fail.  It is difficult to factor if you don't know your multiplication facts.  It is difficult to find the slope of the line if you don't understand the concept of a fraction or how to plot points, which in turn makes it impossible to find the equation of a line given 2 points.  If students had a solid foundation in elementary school, and were held accountable through middle school, they would be more successful in the high school and college level math courses."

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: In regards to grouping I believe that it has been done in the past with the best of intentions.  Administrators and teachers believed that students would be best served to be taught with others who would progress at a similar rate of understanding.  With all the new research and awareness of how this in not most beneficial to learners we need to shift our thinking and utilize students' strengths to the benefit of all who are in a class.  One of the best examples of this I find is when students peer teach.  They can talk out their understanding and ideas while at the same time seeing another persons perspective.  _x0007_One of the comments that resonated with me was when Jo talked about teaching to the middle of the pack and not challenging students enough.  I feel very strongly that all students need to feel challenged and that even those who might require additional support when learning something new should still be challenged to engage in the more difficult problems.  We as teachers can easily adjust the volume f work that is assigned to students, but we should not sacrifice the complexity of the material believing that our students are not capable of handling it.  _x0007_I teach at a school where the majority of our students have diagnosed LD (approx 75%) and the remainder have either undiagnosed challenges learning in a typical school environment or have had very negative past experiences and wish to learn with a more structured and supportive environment.  We have often grouped our classes on perceived ability.  We are starting to move away from this classification in the hopes that we can still provide the necessary support for each student but also expose each of them to challenging material.  As I mentioned above, I believe that past grouping was done with their success put first, but perhaps not in recognizing that this was not the case.  I am looking forward to seeing how a more heterogenous group will perform and I am excited to see some of my students who have not had success in the past work through challenging material and succeed.

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I think that the thinking about Gifted Education has shifted dramatically over the past ten years, and has been shifting for close to 15 years.  I live in Fairfax Co., VA just outside of Washington, DC, and it has been considered one of the most progressive areas in the country for gifted education.  [Not bragging so much as providing context]  While we still have a system that 'groups' gifted kids for services at the elementary level (called Level IV Centers), the thinking amongst the Gifted leadership is that while Level IV Centers are a valuable opportunity for students to work with like-minded peers in a setting with high expectations and extended curriculum, it may not be necessary to achieve the desired outcomes through those centers exclusively.  The county is in the process of expanding the capacity of all teachers to differentiate in any classroom, providing resource teachers to facilitate differentiation and learning, and raising the expectations for all students.  We are working with a population where a significant number of students come to school well-prepared for a challenging curriculum, and whose parents are largely well-educated and committed to high standards for their children.  [Again, not bragging].  I also know that many of the Title 1 schools lag behind on achievement benchmarks not because of staff limitations, but because the cultural/socio-economic factors affecting student achievement haven't been sufficiently addressed to ensure success for those students. _x0007_I'm always interested in hearing from teachers/parents in less-affluent or metropolitan areas how gifted education is perceived and approached.  I think it is dangerous to think that students can only be served in one particular model.  I believe we need to move more toward Differentiation for Learning than separating populations based on perceived need at one particular time.

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I don't believe that students fail for any single reason. Just as teaching is complex, so is the actual learning of mathematics.  From my personal experience as an Algebra teacher for 7 years, I've observed a snow ball effect of sorts. I think it starts with a single bad experience that then continues to compound over and over again. For our students who are chronically underserved by the mathematics classroom, I believe that a continuous sense of failure prevents them from engaging in the material.  The students continue to move on year after year, but they never build any content knowledge. By the time they are in middle school they are facing this huge wall of fractions, decimals, number lines, that they never really understood, and now  they have to apply it to Algebra and more abstract thinking. The classroom sizes at middle school are huge and if the teacher hasn't mastered classroom management, small groups aren't likely to happen which means these kids, the ones who need it most, aren't getting the individual attention they actually need. _x0007__x0007_I don't believe that any one factor is completely at fault, but we have a system that isn't working.

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I am a teacher of high school music and we labour severely under the popular perception that music is a 'gift' or a 'talent' - that somehow you either are musical or you are not. Thankfully, the flipside of the disinterest my administrators feel in my subject means that I have a huge amount of freedom in regard to pedagogy and curriculum. _x0007_One of the most successful changes I have implemented as the Head of Department is in the area of assessment. Instead of formal tests or exams each student fills in a profile sheet at the beginning of each term. The sheet asks them to specify six goals (one each in six areas of skill) from a selection which spans a large range of proficiencies (from beginner/primary to tertiary level).  Students self-assess where they want to work on this sliding scale and what they believe they want to/need to achieve in order to progress. We discuss this in groups (and individually if necessary) but I will never change a student's selection.  They then have all term to demonstrate their six skills to the class and themselves at any time they choose. They can have as many attempts at demonstrating the skill as they like, every week if they choose or only once a term if they choose. Once they have demonstrated understanding by applying it successfully to a problem (not one posed by me but one that they or their peers came up with), I sign their profile sheet and congratulate them. Seems to work really well...motivated kids who apply themselves to the practice some of these skill take and who put thought into how their skill development can be used in real-life problem solving.

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: As many have noted, all of these seem to play into one-another. If we work backward from where the problem exists, perhaps there are issues around *how* material is presented at the college level. This can be compared to how it is presented at the 7-12 level, often reflected in procedures/formula-focused-content-specific \drive\" to complete chapters. The material is presented from the math-expert's (teacher) standpoint, the single-subject teacher; whereas, at an elementary level the material is (hopefully) presented from a teaching standpoint, the multiple-subject teacher with methods courses behind him/her to support teaching/learning for all. At the next level, again moving backwards, it is possible that Algebra continues to be the \"gate-keeper,\" as our math department chair calls it. If students are successful in Algebra, the doors open to other mathematics. It is essential that students *understand* the material of course, so simply earning an A in Algebra is not equivalent to long-term understanding or conceptual synthesis. Moving along, it is also possible that students simply do not have the foundational knowledge necessary for success - which loops all of these together. How are we teaching elementary students? Are we teaching for understanding? Are we assessing FOR learning rather than as a measure to check the end of the chapter in a book? Are we using multiple approaches and are we considering multiple procedures for finding an answer? Is the \"right\" answer (the algorithm) always the answer itself? Do we discuss math and make it part of common classroom culture (much like the literacy corner or Word Wall)? The list goes on... but leads back to the foundational understanding which links to the last thought: students believe they don't have the ability. I will end by saying math came easy to me, I breezed through math in ES and MS, it became a bit more challenging in HS but I relied on my ability to memorize and use formulas in MS to make the most of HS math. College courses in undergrad were mostly GE requirements, and later methods courses for my teaching credential; however, it wasn't until I was *teaching* math that I finally UNDERSTOOD what the underlying mathematics were. I have had so many epiphany moments since beginning as a 2nd grade teacher 15 years ago."

I wish them to be exposed to many different methods of thinking.  We call this a three part lesson (the third part being a whole group review of the work of the students where they comment on the math).  I am sure others are using it.  At first everyone wants to work with the 'smart' person in the class, but over the course of the year that changes.  I had never thought about it before, but I think this goes a long way toward dispelling the myth that only some can learn math.  The students see that even the students who may struggle can come up with great strategies to overcome their own struggles and this inspires others to do the same.

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: As Jo stated the reasons for low achievement among tracked students, I couldnt help but recall my experiences in tracked classes where all of these things happened.  Students who were clearly far above the others in terms of their understanding were not challenged at all because the class was taught to the middle and low-achieving students in the class.  The teacher had low expectations of students and often reminded me that we were constrained in what we could teach because they were the low kids.  Students clearly picked up on this and began to have low expectations for themselves as well, not turning in work or completing assignments that they viewed as busywork (because they were!!)._x0007_	_x0007_I am currently reading Robyn Jacksons book, Never Work Harder Than Your Students.  In this book, Jackson discusses the idea of tracking using the analogy of jumping over a rope.  She explains it in the following way: suppose your goal is that students will be able to jump over a rope that is at least two feet off the ground.  If you set up a rope two feet off the ground exactly, the students who can do it immediately will have nothing to do once they jump over it once or twice, and the students who have trouble will continue to struggle with a static, repetitive task.  If you set the rope up seven feet off the ground, you run into the same problem, but this time you have more students struggling and receiving messages that they are not good enough.  If, however, you set up a rope that is two feet off the ground at one end, and 10 feet off the ground at the other, students are able to grow and challenge themselves, no matter what their starting point.  The key with this is that regardless of their starting points, all students are at the very least exposed to the high expectations further down the rope.  Even the students who are working to jump over a two-foot-high rope can anticipate moving along the rope towards the 10-foot end.  It is this heterogeneous grouping, where students starting points are respected but where all students are still exposed to a challenging environment regardless of their starting point, that leads to the best learning.

I am lucky to be in a school that does not track students (except when they get to 8th grade and some students take Algebra).  But even within my mixed ability class, I often split them into groups for reteaching using the high, middle, low strategy.  This is what I have always been told was a best practice. ( It is even in \Research for Better Teaching\" when you use the quick sort protocol to make groups.)  I also use random groupings regularly too, so hopefully by using different groups all the time it can throw them off the scent of being tracked.  But let's face it, when all the higher achieving kids are in one group and the strugglers are in another group, they know.  I am lucky to also have a math inclusion teacher in class everyday (I love my co-teacher!).  He often pulls small groups, or when we split them into groups he will work with one and I will work with another. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I teach in the UK to 11 to 16 yr olds. I have been at this same school for 7 years. Every year group is set by 'ability'. This is basically decided on by the test they have at the end of the year before but we also give a teacher assessment and base this on work in class and homework. My Head of Department (HOD) is very reasonable and if we can justify where we think a student should go, then he is willing to listen and often moves that student on our advice. _x0007_I think the reason why we set the year groups is to make teachers lives easier. It is a hard enough job anyway, with OFSTED (government inspectors) rating the school and it's teachers on a scale of 1 to 4. If you are rated as a 3, you are satisfactory but you are made to feel that that is not good enough. Likewise if you are graded a 2, good, you feel you should be achieving a 1, outstanding. Having to fully differentiate every lesson for every class and provide the necessary resources is exhausting. If there was a bank of resources made for every lesson, suitable for every child, it would be possible but there are just not enough hours in the day to create/adapt lessons for everything you could possible need. And an exhausted teacher is no good to anyone. I think it will take a long time to move forward unless more teachers/schools/countries are willing to and have the time to share their good resources. _x0007_This year we are trying an experiment where we are teaching our year 9s as mixed ability except for the 'top' set. We know from research that heterogeneous groups are preferable, which is why - in the 80s - the Swedish concept of \A school for everyone\" was planted. Of course, as Jo says, there can be positive things about dividing student in ability groups every now and then, as long as the groups don't stay constant over a longer period of time. _x0007__x0007_At my school, with about 480 students from preschool (6-year-olds) to grade 9, we are working a lot with high expectations, both between leaders-personnel and teachers-students. In math class the teacher often provides problems in different severity or open tasks that can be solved in many different ways and different levels. I would be very surprised if I walked in to a classroom where everybody worked on the same page in the same book. The schedule is flexible to a certain part so that students who need more time to learn basics can get the extra time with a teacher. _x0007__x0007_As for the national tests, these are first of all a possibility for the schools and the teachers, to get a guideline of how well their teaching applies to the rest of the country. NOT to violate the students... The tests are supposed to be done in a way that allows every student to show his or her strengths. Then, of course, the teacher must adjust to each student. _x0007__x0007_I'm sure that this sounds pretentious, and of course we still have a lot to work with when it comes to individualizing at my school as well, but at least we've come a bit on the way. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I am a little nervous about where this bit about \number talks\" is going because my son had a bad experience with this in 4th and 5th grade. Number talks are part of a method used in Everyday Math which his elementary school adopted. The problem comes back to the difficulty of having a wide range of math achievement in the classroom having one discussion/lesson. Students who see 18 * 5 as a simple problem do not want to talk about how they get the answer more than perhaps once or twice for 5 minutes -- after that they want to move on and they get frustrated when they can't. Specifically, in my son's class the teacher tried a number talk asking how many different ways you can depict the number 8. Students answered things like 4+4, 8*1, 16 / 2, 5 + 3, etc. The talk came to an abrupt end when the answer of \"1000\" was given and a couple kids recognized that it was binary for 8, but the teacher was flummoxed. Teacher credibility hit zero, those few kids decided not to participate in these \"stupid\" discussions again (I overheard them discussing it), and the other kids were probably left mystified."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: <redacted> brings up an interesting question: what will happen as families are able to chose between schools? Peer effects are important. Parents want their children in the \best\" schools, which means not only skilled teachers with a growth mindset but also a student body that is hard working and well behaved.  Many parents want their children exposed to a \"diverse\" set of peers, but that doesn't mean disruptive, bullying, or truant students. It is not clear to me whether the overall trend is toward more choice (e.g. charters) or less (economic stratification and growing income inequality). However, in urban public systems like the one where I teach, I think tracking gives hope to the more resourceful families that they can extract their children from the overall system, which performs poorly, and find a pocket of satisfactory teaching/learning. Examples include special schools with test-based admissions and \"gifted and talented\" programs that start at a very early age. Those exclusive programs receive relatively more resources (e.g. better teachers, facilities), and the students do better."

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I teach in an adult education program that groups students who are working towards their high school equivalency diplomas in the following ways: A. Math intensive classes: for students who are particularly week in math. They spend 75% of their time in class focusing on mathematics and only 25% on other subjects. We do not see them as not having potential - in fact they are often amongst the most literate/literary students we have and can write reasonably well. However, their gaps in mathematics knowledge can often be best addressed with more time spent working on deep open-ended problems. Grouping them in this class allows them more time for math. B an C are more problematic. Of the remaining pool of students we divide students into two groups according to performance on official practice tests for the high school equivalency exam. The B \higher\" group often is composed of students who need approximately one semester to finish their studies, earn their diploma, and apply to college. The C group is composed of students with larger gaps in knowledge, weaker math and writing, and who often need at least a year of instruction to obtain a diploma. In both groups students are assessed formatively and can progress faster or slower than we initially think. They are not \"held back\" by their grouping, in theory. But now I am really thinking more deeply about the B and C grouping, and wondering if this division is necessary or desirable. And what affect it has on student learning in both groups."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I read some of the other comments below, and I think there are some very valid points supporting and arguing against heterogenious groups.  I think what is really the most harmful is when there are classes created for heterogenious groups (i.e. the slow class, the gifted class, the average class.) I think students can start to pick up on which students are where and labels are made, strong labels because they were *placed* there.  Clearly, higher powers believe they should be there, so that's pretty dominating and they'll start to limit themselves to that label and belief in themselves (let alone all that was talked about of teacher's not giving the same work or expectations, so they fall more and more behind over time, affecting their future academically forever).  I think what can work is when students are put into different groups based on performance of different topics in one whole class.  That way, high-fliers can sore and be challenged and lower-achieving can take more time and understand concepts at a slower pace to keep them challenged as well.  It sucks when the teacher has a mixed group so s/he needs to move towards the middle yet that leaves the low and high behind.  I think differenciating instruction can be really beneficial in a mixed class (what's key though is mixing it up per topic-- one student might be great at estimation but need more time with division) so that it is annonymous, kept unlabeled, and changing.  Maybe groups with different learners would benefit also so the \smarter\" could teach and lower achieving could ask questions.  I don't know how the teacher would lift up those lower achieving students to get to the higher achieving if everyone can go at their own base in their group.  Wouldn't the teacher*need* to get to the middle by the end of the unit, for the take away lesson?_x0007__x0007_I think the most harmful is labeling, so keeping classes mixed and perhaps using different heterogeous groups per topic could be helpful. It would still be damaging if the groups always stayed the same and if they were labeled."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Lots of people before me have already posted very eloquently on the problems inherent in math classrooms. I believe that many students don't know how to problem solve and lack the know-how or motivation to keep on going when they hit a stumbling block. Many students just want the answer and the correct sequence for how that answer was derived without really understanding (or caring) about the WHYS of mathematical thinking. Perhaps this most closely relates to choice A given in the multiple choice items. But I don't know if this is the most prevalent problem, really. _x0007__x0007_I think too that students lack a fundamental level of confidence in their abilities to think and reason and learn. If that confidence can be built up, then successes can be experienced and progress made. I've always said that my greatest challenge as an instructor is to teach my students how to learn in general (regardless of content area) - to teach them how to seek out answers, to question, to be curious and use tools (such as technology) to help themselves. A lot of students today just don't persevere in the face of a challenge. That's our challenge though as instructors - to try to help our students combat and conquer that mindset.

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I teach at a high school with four-year grouping in math, and have never seen so many students (along with their parents!) with a fixed idea of what they \should be\" achieving and that they are or aren't \"math\" people, or are or aren't \"geometry\" or \"algebra\" people.  The grouping does streamline our classes (I teach mainly honors and AP classes), but I've wondered for some time at what cost._x0007__x0007_We've had some interesting experiences working \"around\" grouping.  These are a very small subset of experiences from a very specific arm of the possible approaches to math teaching, but I hope you find them enlightening._x0007__x0007_1) We have parents that fight their child's initial placement, usually because they think it's too low.  We've ended up with a solution involving a sort of \"limbo\" Algebra/Geometry integrated course that delays the grouping decision for a year (but is taught at an accelerated level).  While I feel we approach this in a more political way than I would like, I can see that it could have advantages; maybe we're reducing some of the \"borderline casualties\" doing it this way._x0007__x0007_2) For my part, I've tried to open up my AP Statistics class to more students; if a student REALLY wants to take the course, I let them -- our school has them sign a contract outlining the expectations for each AP course they take, so they know what they're getting into. (Disclaimer: I do use teacher recommendations for this process, and for each student, I discuss their past math and English achievement with them, as well as the AP Potential tool -- I try not to set students up for failure.) Our AP Calculus teacher also tries to find students in the \"middle\" groups who might be appropriately challenged by AP Calculus._x0007__x0007_3) Finally, it bears mentioning that all our math teachers look for students to move up and down from track to track from semester to semester.  We usually don't move a student up until the year break, but we may move struggling students down when necessary._x0007_ _x0007_It's hard to say yet how these changes are working out for students long-term, as they've all been fairly recent.  I know, though, that the AP math students in our school are developing persistence with a lot of support, and our test scores aren't too shabby -- most of our \"middle group\" students pass their AP exams, many with 4's and 5's.  In one sense, I do think it gives credit to what we're trying to do with access and equity.  In another sense, who knows what these students could have achieved if they had"

I would start by giving the students a large set of very easy(boring) problems, then discuss why they are boring by using how children learn basics like walking and talking and how our brains need the adventure of trial and error to really learn, develop new synapses. When learning to walk, for example, a child first holds on to something to get up the courage to take that first independent step, falls many times, even cries at times, but eventually walking is so well learned that we no longer even give it a thought because by trial and error, making mistakes, walking become automatic.  When we know how to do something our brains are ready to move on to something else, get bored with the same old thing over and over. The activities would end with making either contrasting and humorous posters of the bored brain and the brain learning, or making their own posters of \"Dare to Learn\", to display in the room until daring to make mistakes has become a firm part of the learning culture."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I work in a high poverty, high minority rural school.  We had some of the worst scores in the state on mandated tests.  The only group that seemed to jump by leaps and bounds and eventually overtook the state averages was 3rd grade.  The 3rd grade had three teachers and at the end of each day they gave a one or two problem exit task around math.  In their schedule they had built in a 30 minute remediation block and every day they would sort the students for 30 minutes using the errors on the exit task.  The next day the grouping would be different.  They jumped 10 to 20 % points each year until they were at nearly 80% meeting standard.  This last year they decided to divide teachers into certain subjects, one teacher math, one reading/writing, one social studies AND math intervention.  To accomplish math intervention, they grouped the kids.  It was set for the year.  Their scores dropped 15% points.  They really do believe they are meeting the needs of this lower group and they have some data (real?) from a certain intervention program that shows this group grew. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Interesting discussion so far! I have taught in large comprehensive secondary schools that used grouping by ability level and also small private schools in which the student populations were simply too small to track students. In the latter case, all students were together and some flexible grouping occurred for core subjects such as reading and maths. I much preferred teaching in the second environment, primarily because the general ethos of the classes were, on the whole, better. The lower sets in the first environment tended to be discipline problems and generally, the esteem in which learning was held was much lower. The higher sets were fun to teach but I don't know that they would have been any less fun if they had included a more comprehensive mix of ability levels._x0007_

_x0007__x0007_I now live in a small island country and have taught in three different schools here. In each, classes were mixed, and there may only have been one class at each grade level, so there has been a wide range of ability levels. These classes have been enjoyable to teach and challenging in a good way. We are forced, as teachers, to differentiate our lessons, and because we are dealing with students as individuals, we are also forced to continually reassess their skill levels. Students are not \stuck\" in one group or another because the teacher is always adjusting his or her perceptions of the students' ability based on current work and progress. There is generally a more positive view of learning in these classes than in the lower and middle ability groups I have taught previously, and a more cooperative relationships between students and teachers and between students themselves. When I have taught very low ability groups in the past, I really felt that no matter how much work I put in, I wasn't raising their achievement very much, and their performance on standardized tests certainly bore out my perceptions. It is very difficult to raise achievement levels in classes where all students have experienced low expectations and low levels of challenge over their whole school careers."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Student tracking/grouping has been a hot topic in math for the last several years.  I set my classroom up with students sitting in groups of 3 or 4.  The trick is how do I know what students to sit with whom in order to produce the best results for all students in each group.  Mixing groups with high, middle, middle, low is recommended so that the low student can learn from the high and the high student can teach the low.  The other side of the coin is to group students based upon ability.  The high students sitting all together are suppose to push each other to achieve better and the low students much work to learn since no high student is in the group to give out answers._x0007__x0007_So what do I do???  I am thinking of putting my students together by current score in my class.  With round of assessment, student groups change.  A student who might have been in the low group one unit of learning can find him/her self in the high group with the next assessment.  I will also be placing the lower groups in the front of the room and the higher groups in the back.  This will also hopefully get the lower groups more engaged in the class since they can no longer hide behind their classmates.  The higher students will continue to vie for teacher attention no matter where they sit._x0007__x0007_A colleague of mine who use this practice last year, found that her students quickly raised their assessment scores so no one what sitting in the front of the room, directly next to the teacher desk (the low of the lows).  My colleague never told the students how she was seating them, they intuitively figured it out and made sure their personal level of achievement was high enough to keep them away from teacher.

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: First may I say, I really am beginning to appreciate how forward thinking my school is!_x0007_We don't stream (possibly an Aussie term but synonymous with tracking or setting) in our school ever, in fact, streaming is a dirty word in the Mathematics department. _x0007__x0007_Instead we work in heterogeneous groups, including in my class at least, one student with learning disabilities that have him working two to four years below the others. We set the students to task and formatively assess those with a particular common error.  We then ask these students to join what we call a fluid group, to focus on this particular area.  Students know that, although they are part of the focus group one lesson that is not likely to be the case the next lesson.  The key is their ability to move between groups._x0007__x0007_One thing I find though, is that students I now identify as being fixed mindset high achievers, sometimes seem to resent bein given the same materials to work on as the other students.  We  try to stretch these students horizontally rather than vertically.  Ie.  Rather than 'teach them the formulas to remember from the next year's work, which incidentally would not challenge them,we stretch their understanding of the concept by having them explore the overriding concepts and how they can be applied in new and novel ways.  They despise having to explain their understanding and articulate their reasoning, but that is what they are required to do.

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I was taught about that similar study Jo mentions about the teacher having higher expectations so the random group of students performing at the top of their peer group when I was in college. It shaped my whole way of thinking and I've been adamantly against ability grouping since I started teaching. Every time it's brought up, I fight it. I have been unsuccessful in fighting ability grouping for 1/2 an hour a day in my building for a language arts piece. In math, however, I chose to ability group when I first started adapting my teaching to allow for more open tasks like the ones we've discussed here in this lesson. I felt that by making smaller groups I would be able to better manage my classroom with minimal chaos as a rookie teacher. My math results were good the first few years and I've received a lot of praise for my math. Unfortunately, it's not my math approach that's being respected, but rather the groups. I stopped doing groups last year as I finally grew comfortable enough to approach open tasks as a whole class and still feel like I was meeting all student needs and I continue to see good scores.Those looking at my classroom continue to neglect the approach I take and continue to think I still ability group. It is something that is highly praised and in some cases has been forced in my building. In order to add something productive to this discussion, I will say that Jo's point about teaching to the middle when ability grouping and being more aware in heterogeneous groups and therefore differentiating is true. Creating an environment for a growth mindset is key. Students work together and the teacher can work with a student and give feedback, but it's actually much easier to differentiate in these types of classrooms because mistakes are embraced and questions are encouraged.
