They were told to bring to class all sorts of cylinders, from bicycle wheels to bottle caps. I had them move all the chairs towards the walls and measure the diameter of their cylinders and the distance it would roll in one revolution. For the smaller cylinders, I suggested that they measure distance traversed for x revolutions and divide that distance by x for a more accurate measure of the circumference. They had to wait until the next class to find out why the ratio of circumference to diameter is the same for all circles.

Lately I've begun to provide engaging problems for my students to engage in with a partner.  They are expected to work together, or talk with others, and come up with workable solutions.  I ask questions as needed and then we usually debrief at the end of the time about what they noticed, what worked, etc.  It is amazing to me.  Even grouping two children together that have behaviour problems (something I never would have done in the past) leads to thinking and learning.  Not only are they engaging with the math, they are figuring out how to function with another person.  And, seeing themselves as capable and accountable - having something valuable to offer.  So often in the past, these kids would let the 'smart' ones do everything and hang back in the shadows of activity.  They weren't engaged or excited, but let others do their learning for them.  This has all changed.  Everyone is engaged.  Everyone is thinking and learning.  And, everyone is being pushed out of their comfort zones.  (Especially me.) My thinking about my students was putting unfair limits on them.  Never again.

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I work in an elementary school that does not give grades for student work or on the report card.  In the Math classrooms, students are heterogeneously grouped and are encouraged to work at their own pace.  I teach first grade and very rarely are any students working on the same page or concept in the Math book.  In the upper elementary school grades, students could be working on two different Math books completely, depending on how quickly they achieved mastery of a concept.  So, we do not track or group by an achievement or aptitude test, but some students are doing more advanced work because they have worked through and mastered a concept more quickly than others.  _x0007__x0007__x0007_----------_x0007_A downside of what we do is that we rarely meet as a group to discuss and talk about Math concepts.  Work is mostly done on paper, by oneself, independently. Although students can move ahead to more advanced work I wonder if they are really developing any depth of understanding or ability to think flexibly about Math problems.  They are also missing out on important opportunities to collaborate with peers and to explain their thinking.  _x0007_In addition to this, I feel we are still supporting a fixed mindset. Success is judged by the right answer, because the right answer moves you ahead.  Yes, the student's make mistakes, and that is an opportunity for discussion with the teacher.  Yet the student's have to correct those mistakes, so they know that  it is through mistakes that they learn new concepts.  I feel our environment is somewhat unique and deserves more deeper consideration.  However, I do sense that more group discussion is essential.  The question is, what paper work am I going to cut so that I can put in the group discussion work.  This is a great time to figure that out - before school starts.

This helped many students.  _x0007__x0007_I really appreciated that it was only AFTER all of this class / group work that the Teacher introduced the traditional algorithm for dividing fractions. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: In my school we do not track at all (7th-12th)  However, everyone does not necessarily take calculus.  Students have no choice in their math through grade 10. In grades 11 & 12 they pick classes with guidance from their teachers.  The MA state standards and MCAS test says kids have to be able to solve quadratics.  I personally agree with the person above that I don't believe that to be a necessary skill.  Do all kids need advanced algebra...I don't think so, although my school takes pride in thinking that most of our kids will and should.  If we could take away some of the content expectation and focus on the mathematical thinking, we could more easily group heterogeneously.  When we track, we put kids on a fixed path that due to prerequisites, they can never veer from.  Kids can go down a level, but in math, it is hard to go up a level as usually math is tracked in such a way that kids in upper levels take courses a year early.  So if someone gets stronger in math as they age, they haven't had the prerequisites to move into the upper level without taking a make up course.  With heterogeneous grouping and playing with abilities within a class, all students have the same basic concepts but can develop them to different depths.  If a student better understands one concept over another, they can move more deeply into that concept and spend more time on the basics of another.  Their pacing varies over the course of the year.  The problem right now is that college counselors are pressuring kids to take calculus to be competitive for colleges.  I find myself fighting this constantly with the argument, that I'd rather have the student take a course more suited to their current development and do well, then to take a course that looks challenging on paper only to \fail\" or feel like they are failing. There is a top-down affect.  High schools want to prepare kids to be successful in college, middle school wants to prepare kids to be successful in high school, etc. But in doing so, we are not necessarily doing what is developmentally appropriate at each grade level.  We need to take their brains where they are and work within the developmental confines of them at that point.  Learning can't take place if the work is too easy OR too hard."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: At the small school that I taught at our classes were heterogeneous by necessity. We could only offer one section of each course, based on student numbers. As Dr. Boaler mentioned, this forced us, as teachers, to realize the very different levels present in any one class and teach accordingly. One instructional approach that I found particularly effective was math stations. Math stations are typically used at the elementary level, but they also work REALLY well at the HS level. I was able to differentiate through stations, where students were all working on the same content/concepts, just with different scaffolds available through certain stations. For example, while 5 of the 6 stations were the same for all students, one station offered two \at level\" and \"above level\" options for students to consider. Also, if certain students needed initial help, I had them start at the \"teacher-facilitated station\" so that I could start them strong in the process. Tracking, and its detriments, is something I am interested in learning more about."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: At the end of last year, I happened upon a product in Teachers Pay Teachers called the L.I.N.K. Math Workshop Framework by Colleen Patton.  It is basically a guided math program that uses both whole group, small group, mixed ability and similar ability groupings with rotations.  LINK stands for: _x0007_L - Learning with manipulatives_x0007_I - Independent work_x0007_N - New math_x0007_K - Keep it up games_x0007__x0007_This is a very empowering program.  On Mondays, you preview the week.  Then half of the class is doing an extension of previous learning and/or a preassessment of a coming unit while the other half is doing Linking Leaders and Co-leaders, DISCOVERING how to play a new game that they can teach the others.  every day, they all write in their math journals about something they learned that was significant to them.  On Tuesday through Friday, the teacher presents 2-3 minilessons, meet with 2-3 groups, and students will go to a LINK._x0007_After analyzing the pre-assessments, the teacher divides the class into two seperate groupings.  The first is a mixed ability group that gets a mini lesson on the current whole group unit of study.  The students are strategically paired so that they have a partner to work with at the independent station, even though they will have different assignments, in case they have questions.  They have the same partner for at least one week.  All students are also grouped into similar ability groups, where the teacher can focus on a common area of need with each group.  There are 4 mixed groups, but only 3 similar ability groups, allowing for one extra session for the similar ability group with the most needs.  These groups are very fluid based on the assessing.  at the end of every lesson cycle (between and after the mixed ability groups and the similar ability groups), there is a check in session with all students at the carpet to talk about their experiences and strategies.  I am just getting ready to implement this, as I see it as a powerful way to implement Rti (Response to Intervention) within my own class.  I feel it is important to give all kids what they need, and this is a way to validate each student.  I was always in higher groups, because we were tracked in high school, but my best friend was in the dummy classes.  They were all given D's to pass and never learned anything.  She didn't know how to make change or multiply or anything when she graduated.  I never want any student of mine to feel useless because all students can reach a level of success

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: There are so many enlightening things that Cathy displayed during her number talk. The first was that when she asked the students for answers to the question 25 x 29 and one student gave his answer, Cathy asked if anyone else had a different answer. That is good because some teachers might just start lecturing; however another student said her answer and the first student quickly realized his mistake. This leads into the next thing i noticed. Instead of going forward describing the right answer, Cathy wanted to follow through with how the first student got his incorrect answer. Afterward, cathy acknowledged that the question was hard, mentioned that his thought process was interesting and asked if other students made a similar mistake. I think that during the class discussion acknowledging the question was difficult is a huge deal, because it then makes it ok if someone got the question wrong. Cathy also called the students incorrect thought process \interesting\" which is much better than say words like \"wrong\" or \"incorrect\". Finally, Cathy engages the entire class again by asking if there were similar mistakes made. _x0007__x0007_Later on in the number talk, Cathy asked if any of the students solved the problem in a completely different way and put those answers on the board. Lastly, one thing that stood out to me was when Cathy asked the students to express the different methods in drawings or equations, she asked the students to write on their desks with their fingers. This is a subtle point but it is allowing the students to bring the problem from the abstract word in their minds to the physical world, on the table. This is an important observation because sometimes students get lost in process of their mind and its better to have things written out or, in this case, air written so the students can \"see\" the problem better."

Then the number of blocks in the columns to the left and right of each block decrease by 1.  _x0007__x0007_So the 4th case:  1 2 3 4 5 4 3 2 1_x0007__x0007_So the 100th case:  1 2 3 4 5 6 ... 98 99 100 99 98 97 ... 4 3 2 1_x0007__x0007_Now if you add the total number of blocks in each case:_x0007__x0007_1st case:  1 2 1             = 4_x0007_2nd case:  1 2 3 2 1         = 9_x0007_3rd case:  1 2 3 4 3 2 1     = 16_x0007_4th case:  1 2 3 4 5 4 3 2 1 = 25_x0007__x0007_The total for case 1 is 2 squared = 4._x0007_The total for case 2 is 3 squared = 9._x0007_The total for case 3 is 4 squared = 16._x0007_The total for case 4 is 5 squared = 25._x0007__x0007_The pattern for the total for each case appears to be the (case # plus 1) squared._x0007_Therefore, the total for case 100 is 101 squared = 10,201

Mistakes are just a part of learning and improving. I would have students picture themselves learning how to ride a bike. I would have a couple of students share their experience. Everyone when learning to ride a bike falls off, and when this happens you just don't give up and walk away. No, you pick yourself up and get back on that bike, and continue trying. The more effort and time you spend the better you got and the less you fell. Until one day you were able to ride without falling.the same is true in our class, when you make a mistake, you shouldn't just throw up your hands and give up. You need to continue to work on the problem, until you have solved it. Making mistakes is a important part of our lives, everyone makes them and they help us learn and grow.

Are these students proving to be better problem solvers at the collegiate level? _x0007__x0007_From the Stanford website: 96% of the newly admitted Freshman ranked in the top 10% of their high school class, and 98% scored >600 on the Math SAT. Stanford cites academic rigor as being paramount in the applicant's high school schedule. They say on the website that the typical student completes \four years of math with significant emphasis on fundamental mathematical skills (algebra, trig, plane, solid and analytic geometry)\" and they include calculus on the list of classes they are expecting from most students.  _x0007__x0007_If this is what admissions counselors are looking for at Stanford, it can be difficult to *sell* the idea of an integrated curriculum, especially one that does not end in calculus, in certain communities (like the one where I teach). _x0007__x0007_I'm **NOT** suggesting that students who are the product of an integrated math curriculum aren't as skilled or as well prepared; I am just saying that it's hard to change secondary school math education when there is a *perception* that the integrated path might negatively influence college admissions to certain high profile schools. The Stanford website talks about a holistic review of the admission application, but the hard data they provide seems -- at least to me -- to be skewed toward a traditional math pathway. _x0007__x0007_Again -- I'm not trying to be provocative. I am struggling with this issue in my classroom and in my district. I'd love to hear what others think about this topic, especially if Professor Boaler could comment on what she is seeing at Stanford."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: The information in this session has changed my thinking about my own ability in many ways. For one, it actually transformed a negative attitude that I had placed on myself. I grew up in a low income area and for the most part had really bad teachers. I attribute the fact that I am not \smart\" because I was never properly taught. When I share with people how I felt when I got into a good university, I always say, well, college was hard, I'm not smart, but I just had to work really hard and that's all I could do. Even though my mindset may have sounded like the growth mindset, it wasn't. My mind set was based on the fear of failing and that there was nothing smart in me that I could tap into and therefore had to work hard. Did I appreciate working hard? No. I complained about it every single day wishing that I was smart or could have been taught better in school. So, when I encountered problems that were difficult, I didn't give up, not because I knew I could eventually solve it or that the learning was in the process. I continued to persist because I knew everything was always this difficult. But the difference is with my mindset and the growth mindset is that I did eventually give up. I just wasn't smart enough and I didn't have the energy to put in the hard work to understand. It just \"wasn't going to be my thing.\" But after listening to these lessons, I will now truly have a growth mindset. Now I know that I can work hard to solve these problems and create those synapses I didn't have. Is it true that part of my reasoning for being \"dumb\" is that I wasn't taught it. Yes. But now I know, I can always create those synapses on my own."

Sometimes we would do paired work, where ability didn't matter, but both students had to be prepared to show their work and understanding. In the end it is important to PROMOTE a POSITIVE attitude in the class, encourage discussion and encourage mistakes, and have a great rapport with your students.

I want to be clear with them that they don't know all that they need to know for Math and that's why everyone will make mistakes - because it is through their mistakes that they will learn.  However, this is not a new message - I have been giving this message every day in class since I began teaching Math.  When students make mistakes I work with them to help them \fix\" their error(s).  I think what will be new is that I will start having students share their mistakes and having the group talk about what the mistake is and why the student made that mistake.  Instead of me being the one to always sit down with the student to help them see their error, now I will allow the students to talk their way through the error.  This will, I hope, serve 2 purposes.  First we will be doing a lot more 'class talk' around what we understand about Math.  Second, knowing the enthusiasm of my students, they will all want a turn to be highlighted as the \"Math Learner of the Day\" and so mistakes will begin to be viewed in a positive light as they come with the prestige of being the center of attention at circle time."

You found slope, then used the point-slope formula to write an equation and computed the value of y. It is utilization of particular rules, algorithms and procedures. This is also called the functional approach in learning algebra, because you have used a rate of change and variation. Your second approach where you had to look at the figures and generalize is a structural method. It is focused om underlying structure and patterns. You have moved away from the contextual problem and developed ability to generalize the patterns using different ways and following procedures in a systematic way to get the formula. You have been developing or discovering the relationships and no formulas have been given. This is also called the conceptual learning.

We tried a wide variety of things to get out of this rut, new curriculum, online instruction to \fill holes,\" even new teachers and it seemed that everything we tried failed. As a staff (even non-math teachers) read Jo Boaler's book last summer (2012) and many of us (even non-math teachers) are taking this course. We have decided to \"untrack\" our math classes (and all the others) and so far this year I am seeing students being asked to do far more than they were previously expected to do in both math and other classes. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: So far I have found this issue of education to be a see-saw of terms. Tracking, non tracking, ability grouping, sets, etc. Does it matter what it  is termed if it is working? or does it matter  what it is termed if it is not working?_x0007_I just read a long article of the pros and cons of tracking and I think that the only difference between the two is the perspective of the reader/teacher/administrator. If I have a child with high(is this pc) ability then of course I would want my child to be with other high achievers. If my child was a low (is this pc) then I would still want my child to be with the high achievers hoping that some form of osmosis would cause some of the high learning to rub off on him or her. _x0007_As a parent I have always demanded (yes I was that parent) the same excellence in teaching from my  children's teachers as I demanded in learning from my children. My children were products of public schools and since I was a tax-paying parent (and cheap to boot) I made sure I followed my money. I encouraged teachers and helped teachers and I put in time with teachers to help my children achieve.  In the school system we had at the time we had what were called magnet schools. I did not like them then and still do not.  My oldest daughter attended the top magnet school in our city and earned a scholarship to Berea College. My daughter did everything there was to do to gain entry into the magnet school because she was a high learner, right? And because I do not support separating students into magnet schools I refused to assist her. My feelings are that all teachers are paid the same and all children should be taught the same. My youngest daughter did the same thing got entry and then failed out but she graduated with top honors (1 of 8) in her regular public school. She even taught (yes, taught) her 12th grade math class for the first semester because they had no teacher and used a Dummy book I bought for her because of my own weakness in math. So what does this say about tracking? I don't know, all I know is that my children are successful today.

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I will be teaching an academic strategies class (aka test prep) this fall; two sections, all 11th grade students. I am not willing to merely do review for test prep for 18 weeks, so we are starting the year with a unit about the brain. We will be exploring what happens in the brain when learning occurs, what conditions are optimal for learning, what we can each do to make our brains ready for learning, etc. In this unit, we will be discussing a lot of what we've talked about in this course--how synapses need to fire to make neurons grow, and that if that's not happening learning isn't really occurring. I think many of the students I will be working with are already disenfranchised with the \test culture\" they've been working under most of their school careers. Many of them have determined that they are \"too dumb\" for \"school stuff.\" My hope is that this unit of exploration about the brain will help them to see that they're brains are all functional, all capable, and that they all have potential to improve their skills in any area. I'm intending this to be a rather motivational unit, and to then encourage them to explore what areas of learning they feel most interested in. I will then encourage them to pursue answers to some deep questions in those areas throughout the course. _x0007_So, my message to my students this fall will be: You have a brain. It is functional, capable, and full of potential. There are some very basic things you can do to make your brain grow. Make use of what you have and it will only get stronger!_x0007__x0007_(This post is in response to video session 3, part 10)"

Society, parents, teachers, and the students themselves reinforce this mindset, which will make changing it very difficult. The battle to change fixed mindsets must be fought parent by parent, student by student, classroom by classroom, school by school, and so on. Ability grouping (except in small doses) reinforces this mindset, but the fixed mindset probably is a main reason schools and teachers resort to ability grouping in the first place, which sets up a vicious circle. At my elementary school, we have heterogeneous regular math classes in which students of very different abilities work on the same lessons, sometimes as partners, sometimes individually. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Schools will, I have no doubt, have the self perception that they already take on the growth mindset, even before this new evidence was produced; which school would say otherwise? Every school that I have been involved in has tracking systems monitoring the progress of students, incorporates minimum levels of expected progress over five years, one year, six weekly on which the teacher, department and school has to report back where targets have been met or otherwise. This alone indicates that they believe that students should make progress. The structure within mathematics for progress is based upon the 'ladder' which Paul Lockhart so eloquently  describes at the end of his 'Lament' essay. This is the working context that schools choose to work in, and so the growth mindset has to be linked to achieving the next level or grade. To remove this constraint in our present context may only improve the growth of  a few whilst marginalising the majority, whose motivational reality remains the 'grade'. As it stands in the UK, schools now have the choice to adapt the curriculum to their own needs; I would like to see mathematics departments reduce the ratio of objectives to time, in order to explore and develop the range of mathematical experiences for each objective, whilst still maintaining the 'reality of grades', to improve the learning of mathematics.

I was able to spend alot of time giving my students a solid foundations in the basics but it was not what my students in 6th grade were missing. I was then moved to 3rd grade with the intention of looping with my students. In third grade is where I started to see huge gaps. It was at this time I decided it was due to the pacing I had to follow. We are told what to teach, when to teach it, how to teach it, and for how long. For example I was only allowed to teach multiplication for 3 days. That is a huge concept student must have a solid understanding of to build on. Division we spent a week on. I saw my students struggling and getting further and further behind but I was told to press on and they will eventually \get it\". _x0007__x0007_Part of the pacing is an instructional cycle. It is a vicious cycle that does not make sense to me. _x0007__x0007_Using the information I learned through all my moves I decided to look at the gaps my third graders came to me with (i.e. subtraction) and look at the second grade pacing guide. If we are not giving them a solid foundation to build upon when they are young how on each to we expect them to be able to do higher level math? Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: . _x0007_    I remember reading about this in _What's Math Got To Do With It_, and I, too, wanted to figure out some way to convey this to the rest of the world so they'd understand it, because these \uncompressed math\" learners and so many of their teachers assume that they just can't get fluent..._x0007_      I think, perhaps, that Sebastian hasn't been in the minds of an awful lot of folks, though.   He assumes that they're \"mathing\" things when... no, not necessarily.   Lots of functional citizens *don't* engage in even the basic mathy stuff.  To them, it *isn't* all addition with flair, compressed and elaborated.   Lots of 'em have forgotten the addition in their avoidance of that nasty stuff called math. _x0007_      I was having some students review a video lesson from Algebra2go ( http://www.saddleback.edu/faculty/lperez/algebra2go/ ) about perimeter, and adding numbers, and one student thought the *best* part of the video was when he reminded the students (from a previous lesson these folks hadn't seen) that they could do \"Kung Fu Math\" and put the easy-combo numbers together first and then do the rest.  In our pre-pre-algebra course, we're going to do a *lot* of building those \"tricks\" -- and why they work ... ifI can find time to build those lessons in the next three weeks ;) _x0007_     Another one of my ladies, this morning, was wrapping her mind around the connection between multiplying by a half, taking half of something, and dividing by two.   Watching her shift from the calculator to figuring out mentally that if the diameter is 206, the radius is 103, warmed the cockles of my heart :)_x0007_    We put together a sort of \"crash course in concepts\" last spring, borrowing from Dorothea Steinke's \"part and whole\" work ( http://www.ncsall.net/index.php@id=70.html has the link to a neat article about it) and Marilyn Burn's math concept inventory ( https://mathreasoninginventory.com   ) .   Oh, my, the number of people who \"used the standard algorithm\" for, say, 1000 - 997... mentally! That analogy of the ladder is painfully valid.  Even with just seven sessions, they were more successful when they dove into pre-algebra (hence our hope that a full semester of conceptual preparation for pre-algebra will have an even better effect)."

I've noticed that \seeing\" numbers geometrically allows students to deal with them more effectively. Take factoring for instance. factoring a whole number is just creating a rectangular arrangement. Finding the GCF of two whole numbers is equivalent to creating two rectangles where a dimension matches--the longest such match. _x0007_As you move into more abstract mathematics, binomial distribution can be visualized geometrically in this manner. Even simple proofs like the addition of two odd numbers always being even depends on a geometric representation of number. _x0007_At its core is the belief that math contains multiple solution paths. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Our school has been experimenting with different models of grouping students._x0007__x0007_When we had mixed ability groups I can say that it didn't work well - lower achieving students lacked the confidence and belief that they could achieve more highly then they expected.  They became frustrated and disruptive.  This is probably due to them having already been labelled 'low ability'.  The higher achieving students soon ran out of material and some would sit, after they had finished their exercises content to do nothing else.  The problem here seems to be the tasks that we have given the students - not open enough.  In order to begin to teach students in a mixed group you would need to do an immense amount of groundwork, giving them confidence, training them in how to be more independent and self-starting, preparing the kind of tasks during a lesson that ALL of them could do and still learn from._x0007__x0007_A second type of grouping we tried with lots more success was based on a pre-assessment.  This would be done several times during the year.  The pre-assessment would indicate a general aptitude (eg, with algebra, number, data or shape) and we would group the students based on this.  However, the students would still know whether they were in the top or bottom group so I imagine that this would promote a fixed mindset too._x0007__x0007_I want to have my students in mixed groups - the research indicates that this is the best thing to do after all.  The difficulty is HOW then do I teach them?  The ability range is so vast on occasions.  Perhaps you could also say that their learning styles are also far apart (I suspect that the 'high achievers' are more passive, are able to concentrate, do not mind sitting still, whereas the 'low achievers' are more active, want to be up out of their seats, chatting, playing, doing).  I find this a practical issue of how to differentiate and manage behaviour.

I also teach at a school where they are trying to de-track the freshman experience, because of how inequitable it is in terms of judging them based on one test.   There are lots of politics, and it is difficult for a parent who has a \"high achiever\" to see the benefits they get in a classroom filled with students who have disengaged, and create significant distraction.  I don't think they inherently don't like these students, but are worried that their lack of focus and need for attention will take away the valuable instruction time their student needs.  What we all need to realize is that in order to teach, we need to create tasks that create entry points for all students to learn and grow, regardless of how they attack it.  They only way that we can do this, is to do it together, and spend less time focusing on how different our classroom's are, and focus more on how much leverage we can get from each other."

Some students do it all of the time, and all students do it some of the time._x0007_And, it's true, an outside observer can't tell what's going on in such a student's brain. Plus, all brains need to coast now and then -- learning isn't necessarily about being intense or ultra-focused or good at giving speeches._x0007_Some students are shy, or receiving messages that damage their self-esteem from somewhere outside the class, and a class where participation is forced can be painful to them and make them retreat further._x0007_Here's where teaching experience can help the teacher gain enough sensitivity to know when to engage a particular student or students and when to let them observe and tag along. If the teacher gives the student a little leeway, the student may well gain comfort and start participating on his or her own. On the other hand, sometimes the teacher needs to say \"Here, do this\" without giving the student time to object -- cutting through whatever is blocking the student's participation._x0007_Students are used to these peer group situations where some members of the group are seldom active participants and where some are having a bad day -- teachers can learn a lot by paying attention to how students relate to each other within a group._x0007_A teacher can also talk about \"coasting\" and what is an expected and useful degree of participation."

I encourage my teacher ed. students to avoid the word \trick\" in math class (for example, \"Let me show you a trick for memorizing the nines multiplication facts.\")  The language of \"tricks\" and \"magic\" perpetuates this idea  that math is mysterious and unknowable, except to the lucky few with that math gene. You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: One way to group my students that I found to be effective for both quick learners and those who need more time to learn is that I pair these learners together.  So, there is one quick and one slower learner paired together.  Usually the quick learner has quickly completed the task, but because their partner is not able to solve it as quickly, it causes the quick learner to slow down, reprocess what was done, and then explain it to their partner.  Then the slower learner is able to hear how the problem was solved, talk it over with their partner, and try to solve in the same way, or perhaps in a different way.  Then both partners come up in front of the class and must each explain one portion of how they solved the problem.  This helps both my learners to do the work and feel responsible.  When they solve it incorrectly, it puts it back on both of them to work together, instead of feeling like they solved it incorrectly because they are in a \low\" group or incapable."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: At the most basic level, math comes down to a simple understanding of numbers; what they mean, how they can be combined and used in different ways. Dot cards would be useful in eliminating the rigid perception of numbers, which cripples students when it comes to higher level mathematics and science. For example, the step into fractions depends on a flexible understanding of numbers and number relationships. Six is not just six; it is also two plus four, three plus three, four less than 10, two times three, and half of 12._x0007_Number sense is internalizing this number diversity and being able to think of numbers in creative ways for problem solving. It is an essential knowledge for math success, because when kids internalize numbers, they become free to think beyond basic calculations to higher-level problem solving.

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: When a senior in my class is soon to graduate, I always inquire, \What next?\"  When students are headed to a 4-year college, they are excited to leave home, room with friends, and start the next stage of their life.  When a student is going to a 2-year college, most have yet to enroll before the year is up, must figure out how to pay for courses, and many use the word probably in their response (as in, Ill probably go to PCC in the fall).  _x0007__x0007_In these conversations, Ive found that the general 2-year college student is not as committed to the idea of taking the next step as their 4-year counterpart.  I ask what drives them or what is their path of interest, and most 2-year students are unsure and say they are going to figure it out when they get there whereas the 4-year student has determined the general field they will pursue at least to get started.  Contributing factors that I always wonder about after these conversations include how much guidance a student has received from a parent/mentor/counselor, the students ability to make decisions and have confidence in those decisions (I could not make these decisions myself but had parent support), and if there is the presence of a positive peer group that has influence over their lifes direction.  We need to build a better bridge to connect the student to the field of interest. _x0007__x0007_This takes me back to the common thread that teachers must do a better job connecting math concepts with their application beyond the classroom and though this has been stated a hundred times and is essential, I believe a student must see themselves personally invested/directly linked to that career path.  We need to make available more work study programs, and require a student to commit to one over a long period of time.  Experience in the field will build confidence and give students more direction allowing for full commitment in whatever path they follow._x0007__x0007_When forced to choose between choices a-d (see I can make decisions now), I would choose b) Lack of Foundational Knowledge, followed by a) The Teaching Methods.  Both are needed to gain confidence and commitmentchicken and the egg, which came first?"

Well, we all know there is no use crying over spilt milk. But this story is different..._x0007__x0007_A boy was trying to remove a carton of milk from the refrigerator when he lost his grip on the slippery milk carton and it fell, spilling its contents all over the kitchen floor a veritable sea of milk!_x0007__x0007_When his mother came into the kitchen, instead of yelling at him, giving him a lecture, or punishing him, she said, Robert, what a great and wonderful mess you have made! I have rarely seen such a huge puddle of milk. Well, the damage has already been done. Would you like to get down and play in the milk for a few minutes before we clean it up?_x0007__x0007_Indeed, he did. After a few minutes, his mother said, You know, Robert, whenever you make a mess like this, eventually you have to clean it up and restore everything to its proper order. So, how would you like to do that? We could use a sponge, a towel, or a mop. Which do you prefer? He chose the sponge and together they cleaned up the spilled milk._x0007__x0007_His mother then said, You know, what we have here is a failed experiment in how to effectively carry a big milk bottle with two tiny hands. Lets go out in the back yard and fill the bottle with water and see if you can discover a way to carry it without dropping it. The little boy learned that if he grasped the bottle at the top near the lip with both hands, he could carry it without dropping it. What a wonderful lesson!_x0007__x0007_Young Robert learned that mistakes are opportunities for learning something new, which is, after all, what life is all about. Even if the experiment doesnt work, we will learn something valuable from it.\""
